hints.content: Start by understanding the constraints of the problem. The array length is always even, which means you can split it into two equal parts. This is crucial for ensuring that both parts have the same number of elements.
Consider the requirement for distinct elements in both parts. Think about how the frequency of each element in the array might affect your ability to create two distinct subsets.

Count the occurrences of each element in the array. You can use a dictionary or a counter to track how many times each number appears. This will help you determine if you can form two distinct groups.
Remember that if any element appears more than twice, it will be impossible to split the array into two distinct parts. Check the maximum frequency of any element in your count.
If the total number of distinct elements is greater than or equal to half the length of the array, you might be able to split the array successfully. Consider how you will check this condition.
Think about edge cases. For example, if all elements are the same, how does that affect your ability to create two distinct arrays? This will help you solidify your understanding of the problem.
You might want to create a simple algorithm that iterates through your count of elements and checks if you can form two groups of distinct elements. Start with the most frequent elements.
If the number of distinct elements is less than half the length of the array, you can immediately return false. This is a quick check that can save you time.
Consider how you will structure your final check to determine if you can split the array. You may need to balance the counts of elements in both potential subsets.

Finally, implement your logic to return true if you can successfully split the array into two distinct parts, and false otherwise. Ensure your checks are efficient to handle the upper limit of the constraints.

questionNotes: The array length is always even.
Both nums1 and nums2 must contain distinct elements.
Return true if a valid split is possible, false otherwise.
Check the frequency of elements to determine the possibility of distinct subsets.
